title: Insane Fuel Saver Scams (Effuel, EcoTune, etc.) - Krazy Ken’s Tech Talk

Although this part is true (it is, in fact, NOT a registered trademark) the product used the  symbol, not the  symbol. The use of  does not require legal filing, and least in the United States. So this is not as bad a red flag as I initially claimed, but I believe it's still misleading.  #KrazyKen #ComputerClan

But, I think we need to clarify a few things because the product claims it plugs into your OBD2 port, and then it communicates with your car's ECU. What are those things? OBD stands for on-board diagnostics, and the "2" simply means second generation. If you have a scanner, this is where you'd plug it in to read DTCs, or diagnostic trouble codes. Oh, look! I have a leak. Well, isn't that splendid? The OBD2 port has 16 pin locations. Seven of them don't connect to anything by default, but they may be used for different functions depending on the vehicle. So now, what's this ECU thing? ECU stands for engine control unit. Basically, it's the brain of your car's engine. It helps your engine work properly, so your car drives how it should. The ECU is a computer with inputs and outputs. The input signals from the engine translate into data. For example, temperature and RPMs. The output signals connect to the fuel injectors, controlling them to achieve the target air-fuel ratio. The ECUs output also connects to the ignition system and controls engine timing by regulating the time in which the spark ignites the fuel. Ultimately, this helps achieve optimal power and fuel economy, which is your miles per gallon. So to sum that up, these products claim they can communicate with the ECU in your car and tune it so your engine runs better. But for a tiny cheap automatic box, that seems really impractical.
